editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Changes: or, love in a maze.
A comedy, as it was presented at the private house in Salisbury court, by the company of his majesty's revels.
London: printed by G. P. for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his shop near furnival's inn gate in Holborn, 1632.

div.head: To the right honourable, the lady Dorothy Shirley.
div.l: Madam, who make the glory of your blood
No privilege at all to be less good;
Pardon the rudeness of a comedy,
That (Taught too great ambition) would fly
To kiss your white hand, and receive from thence
Both an authority, and innocence.
'Tis not this great man ▪ nor that prince, whose fame
Can more advance a poem, than your name,
To whose clear virtue truth is bound, and we,
That there is so much left for history.
I do acknowledge custom, that to men
Such poems are presented; but my pen
Is not engaged nor can allow too far
A Salic law in poetry, to bar
Ladies th'inheritance of wit, whose soul
Is active, and as able to control,
as some 'Usurp the chair, which write a style
To breathe the reader better than a mile;
But no such empty titles but my flame;
Nor will I sin so much, to show their name
In print; some servile muses be their drudge,
That sweat to find a patron, not a judge.
To you, great lady, then, in whom do meet
Candour and judgement, humble as your feet
I vow these papers, wishing you may see
Joys multiplied, to your eternity.

closer.signed: Your honour's devoted servant, I A. Shirley.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: That muse whose song within another sphere
Hath pleased some, and of the best, whose ear
Is able to distinguish strains that are
Clear, and Phoebean, from the popular;
And sinful dregs of the adulterate brain,
By me salutes your candour once again;
And begs this noble favour, that this place,
And weak performances may not disgrace
His fresh Thalia; alas our poet knows
We have no name, a torrent overflows ▪
Our little island, miserable we,
Do every day play our own tragedy:
But 'tis more noble to create than kill,
He says, and if but with his flame, your will
Would join, we may obtain some warmth, and prove
Next them that now do surfeit with your love ▪
Encourage our beginning, nothing grew
Famous at first, and gentlemen, if you
Smile on this barren mountain, soon it will,
Become both fruitful and the muse's hill.

list.item: Master Goldsworth, father to Chrysolina and Aurelia.
Master Thornay gentlemen lovers of Chrysolina, Aurelia and Eugenia.
Master Gerard gentlemen lovers of Chrysolina, Aurelia and Eugenia.
Master Yongrave gentlemen lovers of Chrysolina, Aurelia and Eugenia.

div.head: Changes or, love in a maze.
Actus primus, scaena primas.
div.stage: Enter at one door sir John Woodhamore, and master Goldsworth, at the other m. Gerard, and master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Golds.
sp.p: I heard your niece, sir, was not well, you should encourage her to take the air some times.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Indeed she's somewhat melancholy, and keeps
Her chamber:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: 'T may prove inconvenient for
Her health, does she not languish for a husband?
Take heed oth' green disease ▪

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I'll find a cure,
If that will do't; your daughters are not yet
Disposed of?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: No, but we have clients daily
That visit their affections; and while
We are speaking, here is one.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Ha, which of them? I hope not master Yongrave ▪
He would engage his service to my niece,
I shall not think him worthy, if he have
Two hares afoot.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: He is a stranger to me,
But master Gerard that holds conference with him,
Maintains some correspondence with my daughters:
Pray let's observe.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Prithee come, venture in.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: No farther, you have obligation,
Excuse me, I have affairs, some other time
I'll wait on you.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: What needs this ceremony?
The fair ones will not blast you.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: 'Twere a sin,
To think their beams could hurt ▪

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Faith, I could wish
Thy affection not engaged, there's so much beauty
And goodness in this pair of sisters ▪

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Do not
Make me suspect your friendship, you would wish
Me miserable, not that I dispute
Their merit, but I must not yield to that
Will bring my faith and honour into question;
I have a mistress, be you happy sir in yours.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I like this well, let's interrupt 'em;
Good fortune master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You are sir,
Most opportunely met.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Kind master Gerard.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I had a present resolution,
To visit you at home, and your fair kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I shall be bold.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Pray enter.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: We'll together: I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I am your humble servant,

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Come master Yongrave. Exuent.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: This Gerard is a gentleman of handsome parts,
And they say fortuned, diligent in's courtship:
But it concerns me to be careful in
Disposing of my children.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir Gervace simple sir, is newly entered,

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: His wisdom must be welcome: there's a knight
With lordships, but no manors, one that has
But newly cast his country skin, came up
To see the fashions of the town, has crept
Into a knighthood which he paid for heartily
And in his best clothes is suspected for
A gentleman.

div.stage: Enter sir Ger. simple, and his man Thumpe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thump, I have not yet the face to speak to her, but
'Tis no matter, and I can get her father's and mother's good will.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: You have her mother's already.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ay, ay, she's a matron as they say, I came over her with
My knighthood, and begotten a consent upon her quickly: I
Perceive 'tis an advantage for a man to wear spurs,
The rowel of knighthood does jingle in the ear of their
Understanding.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: I do wonder sir, that you speak so well now, and
Want the audacity as they say to talk to your mistress.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: So do I too, but I cannot help it: I was a gentleman
Thou knowest but tother day. I have yet but a few
Compliments, within a while I shall get more impudence
And then have at her.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: The father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Pray heaven you may be saved, sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You're charitable.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I am come sir to do my business.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You may imagine as they say, and so forth your
Daughter is a very fine gentlewoman, and may in due time be a lady,
for I do love her by this mullet, there's a touch of my heraldry.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Have you acquainted her,
How much you mean to honour us, how far
Have you engaged her liking?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay, I ne'er spoke to her in my life, nor do not mean in haste.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not in haste sir, 'twere no good manners to speak hastily to a gentlewoman, to talk post (As they say) to his mistress; I am resolved to have your consent first, and then.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: It argues your discretion;

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I think so, some wiser than some, faith how do y'like my face.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: I have seen worse in a beard,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O, ho, I took my choice of forty, this morning.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Did you so?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: My man knows I broke a looking ▪ glass into forty pieces,
I am sure, and this was the best face I could find among
'Em all, look in my forehead, hast any skill in palmistry?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: But this is nothing to the purpose (As they say,)
Where is my beautiful mistress, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Which of 'em?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No matter which.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: They are both within.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O, 'tis well, I will not speak with her, I told you
Before, but I hope I shall have your good will.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You mean to marry her.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: My chaplain shall.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You are witty; I hope sir, you will give me leave (As
They say) to deliberate, for after your example, I would
Do nothing rashly, I will not give you my consent in
Hast sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis wisdom, I can tarry, 'tis fit I should, commend
Me to the virgin.

div.stage: As he goes forth he meets mistress Goldsworth.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: What, leaving us already, noble sir?
Why husband, what do y'meane? no more respect
To a man honourable? you're not going sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes faith, I love to be going, I cannot abide to stand
Still, Thump, take off my cloak; does my rapier become me?

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Excellent well.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: This 'tis to be a complete gentleman, what a coxcomb was I before I came to town, the country breeds so many clowns; dost think my tenants will know me now I am disguised

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But what assurance can he give me, wife,
That he is able to get children?
For that's a thing material; I would not
Willingly sacrifice my daughter to
An eunuch, and such a one may that knight be,
For ought I know.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: What do you talk of children?
Is he not honourable, a proper knight?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: She does commend me; do not put on my cloak yet, let her survey my person.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Shall not our daughter be a lady, and I a
Lady's mother? And the heralds know
That is some privilege; you have seen many eunuchs
With a black beard; he is a man I warrant him,
He has the right hair, husband, for a woman,
I know it by experience: tell not me,
Suppose he were an eunuch, he I say
Is honourable, and anybody can get children,
That's the least thing of a hundred
And the woman be but fruitful.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Wil't please you sir, to walk in, and speak to my daughter?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No, I think it not the best way to speak to her, as I said,
In haste, what if I had an inventory of my good parts
First drawn to prepare her.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And his father had not left him more land than brain,
His worship had been but a poor fool.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well, if she understand signs, have at her.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Come, I will direct you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: My wife is passionate and affects this knight
For's title, but I hope my daughter will
Submit to my election: how now:

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here is a gentleman desires access to you.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: A gentleman?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He may be a lord by his train,
A page waits on him.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Some fresh inamorato.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And you sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You do not know me?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis very likely: you have a daughter.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I have two:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Two? the better, there is more choice,
They want husbands.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: 'Twill become my care to provide 'em good ones.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You say well, what do y' think of me?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I know you not.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You told me that afore: may I see 'em?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: They are not to be let out sir by lease,
Or yearly rent.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You mistake me; I come not for a lodging.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Nor to lie with them?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I come to take 'em sir, another way:
What portions have they?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You should be a purse-taker, by your enquiry
After their money, they have a round portion, sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: A cipher.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Nothing. I hope you have no mind to marry.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ex nihilo nihil fit. I came to offer myself a
Servant in affection to one of your daughters, but
Nothing has converted me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Do y'hear sir, a fine humorist: if they marry with
My consent, I can make figures, which added to
Their ciphers, may make up 2000 pound apiece: what
Is your name?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My name is Caperwit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You've a dancing name, I do not think, but you
Write all the corantoes.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Wit! wit by Mercury! I shall love thy daughters the
Better for that: do they affect poetry?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They read nothing else.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Then they are wise; 'tis a seraphic contemplation ▪
I'll furnish them with the most excellent poems —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Of your own composition?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: That is intimated, when I say excellent;
Your daughters shall be judge, let 'em vouchsafe
A subject to my muse, and prove the height
Of my imaginations.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They are entering.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Thus breaks Aurora from the Eastern hills,
And chaseth night away, let me salute
Your rosy cheek —

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Good morrow to you sir, there is but one Aurora,
What do y' make my sister pray?

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.l: She is the sun itself.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: No sir, I am the daughter of that gentleman,
no sun I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Whose golden beams do gild this lower world,
Transfixing hearts, converting ribs of ice
Into a flame.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: What buffoonery is this?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Let's hear his speech out, and my sister be the sun,
We shall have day enough: a pretty pageant!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Prithee do not mind him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Virgins, that equal all the graces, and
Only in this, that you are two, beneath them.
The miracles of beauty! for whose eyes
The Persians might forsake their god, and pay
Religious honour to this flame — what's he?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: A gentleman, that would endear himself.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Has he any fancies in him? Can he ravish
The ladies?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Ravish ladies sir? that's a dangerous matter.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How many raptures does he talk a day?
Is he transported with poetic rage?
When was he styled imperial wit? who are
The prince electors in his monarchy?
Can he like Celtic Hercules, with chains
Of his divine tongue, draw the gallant tribe
Through every street, whilst the grave senator
Points at him; as he walks in triumph, and
Doth wish, with half his wealth, he might be young,
To spend it all in sack, to hear him talk
Eternal sonnets to his mistress? ha?
Who loves not verse is damned —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How sir? This gentleman dares fight.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Who will fight with him?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You do not know his disposition.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
But I will, sir; I have a great ambition to be of your acquaintance, I hope you will excuse these fancies of mine, though I were born a poet I will study to be your servant in prose, yet if now and then my brains do sparkle, I cannot help it, raptures will out, my motto is quicquid conabor ▪
the midwife wrapped my head up in a sheet of sir Philip Sidney that inspired me, and my nurse descended from old Chaucer, my conversation has been among the furies, and if I meet you in Apollo, a pottle of the best ambrosia in the house, shall wait upon you.

div.stage: Enter sir Gervase simple, and mistress Goldsworth.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: They are here sir, at full view.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: A knight I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Does he come
A wooing to the ladies?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: After the Spanish fashion —
Afar off.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Daughter, I must counsel you to respect
This honourable man, you do not know
What 'tis to be a lady, and take place,
Such titles come not every day, observe
With what a comely garb he walks, and how
He bends his subtle body, take him a my word,
A man of his complexion loves a woman naturally.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A pretty motion.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Pray come nearer sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You shall pardon me for that, I know
My distance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Will he not speak to her?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: You should do well to furnish him with an oration, a spoonful of Aganippe's well, and a little of your salt, would season, if not pickle him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Should I so waste the bright Minerva's dew, to pickle a mushroom?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thump, she looks upon me, to say truth, I am but a bashful puppy.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Your worship is more than a puppy.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ay, I know I am an old dog at her mother, but and I should be hanged, I have not impudence enough to speak to her: does not that gentleman laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: He is very merry with her father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis very suspicious, would I had a good jest to get of withal.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You shall command the duty of a daughter,
But I hope mother, you will give me leave
To love before I marry I have yet
No argument of his affection,
But what you please to bring me it becomes not
My modesty to court him, and give up
My heart before I hear him say, he means
to meet and entertain it.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: 'Tis a fault, and I must blame him, that he is no forwarder.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I will accuse him —

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Do so.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Love, forgive me this excuse, my heart is fixed,
I find another written here.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I do salute you, venerable sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You may salute me at your pleasures, but you are mistaken, I am no more venerable than yourself; my name is sir Gervace simple.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: And I am one of his gentleman ushers ▪ sir, that follow him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Heroic sir, I do adore your physiognomy. Now by the dust of my progenitors —

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: There's a fine oath!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You look like the nine worthies.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I have been taken for 'em a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fairer than Pluto's self King of the shades.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: That King was a poor kinsman of mine, and indeed we had one complexion.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: The devil you had?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry, I cannot stay wi'ye, but pray if you meet any of the nine worthies, or my cousin Pluto, commend me to 'em, I shall be glad to meet you, or them, at any tavern, between cheap and Charing-cross, and so I remain yours, or not his own, sau's compliment.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: When will you please sir Gervace, to visit us again? Nay, it shall be yours. He compliments, exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Now my foot's in.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: But that I see't, I should not have believed there were such a fool in nature.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: In this variety of servants, I
Acknowledge you greatly honour me, and in the presence
Of both your parents to vouchsafe this favour,
Doubly obliges me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You are most welcome.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You may believe my sister, she ne'er speaks
But by direction of her heart.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am confident,
Nor hath she any virtue, which you do not
Divide with her; your twins in birth and goodness!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You're bountiful in character.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I'll not oppose you sir, and you can win their opinion.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis enough, I shall be proud to serve you;
But at this present, with your noble licence,
I take my leave, there is a lord expects
to meet me at a tavern, that has come
Fourscore and nineteen mile, to hear an elegy of
My composition

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: He deserves to enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I'll attend the ladies, when my stars will be more propitious, ith' interim wearing your beautiful figures in my heart, I kiss your white hand —Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I think the stock of his discourse be wasted,
And he returns to take up more on's credit,
Until he break again, the town is full
Of these vainglorious flashes.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Chrysolina,
You see what store of servants ye attract,
Plenty of lovers but I hope you will
Be ruled, and take my counsel: which of all
And be plain wi'me, hold you best opinion of?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You will not sir, be angry, if I answer you justly.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: No no, tell me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I confess,
I now do feel the power of love, until
That gentleman —

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Which, which gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: By his fair merit, won my heart's consent,
I had my freedom.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Master Gerard?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: The same, o sir, there's no comparison
With him and those that proffer us their service:
Sir Gervace is but title, tother noise,
Empty of all reality and worth,
There is my choice, more precious to my thoughts,Pointing to Ger.
Than all mankind without him, and I hope
You will be kind in your allowance sir.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You might have used less haste in your election,
Or first acquainted me, you shall do well
To keep possession of your heart awhile;
But I'll consider; send your sister to me:
What say you daughter to sir Gervace?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Nothing, as much as he hath said to me.
I affect worth, not show; and in my choice
I hope your judgement sir will meet.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I like this well, be obedient.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What think you sir, of master Gerard?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You do not love him?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I should then bely
my heart when I deny him my best love,
He needs not boast his worth, like those whom nature
And art have left unfurnished, he's a man
For birth, for education, for his fortune,
Worthy a nobler wife, than she that now
Commends him to you.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Would you marry him?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I know not that man in the world beside,
I would call husband, in my soul I am
Already his, and if you will not be
Held cruel to your daughter —

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: How's this?
Both in love with the same man? my care will be
To a great purpose, this is very strange;
Send your sister to me; come hither, come hither,
You are not yet contracted to that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.l: No such thing has passed.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: But you are content to take him for your bridegroom, I mean master Gerard.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: And call it happiness;

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Your mother calls: so, so, do you hear? Aurelia, do you love that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Very good ▪ when your wedding clothes come home, pray give me leave to pay for 'em, and the dinner too. I say nothing of a portion, go after your sister: hum, this is very pretty, faith, let me be bold to ask you a question sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My answer shall be just, and free.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Which of my daughters do you love best?
As you're a gentleman the truth, if you affect either, it
Is quickly answered.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: The truth is, as you ask, I love neither.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: How, do you love none of 'em both, they are very well rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Love neither of them best, they are so equal in beauty, and desert, by both I swear, I cannot prefer any.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: You'd not have two wives against the statute?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: When I have the happiness to speak with one alone ▪
There's so much sweetness in her, such a troop
Of graces waiting on her words and actions,
I love her infinitely, and think it blessing
To see her smile, but when the tother comes
In presence, in her eye she brings a charm
to make me dote on her; I am divided,
And like the trembling needle of a dial,
My heart's afraid to fix, in such a plenty
I have no star to sail by.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: This is stranger.
Than all the rest, but do you love 'em both?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I dare not call it my misfortune sir,
And yet I know not. —

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: What will become o'this?
Is't possible? My daughter will be mad if this humour
Hold, and I am little better while I think on't:
I'll to 'em again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: On whom shall I complain for my hard fate?
Love is not innocent enough to be
A child, yet poets give him deity,
Fond men! prove it in me, thou quivered boy,
That love with equal flame two mistresses,
I will believe thee a god, and kiss thy dart,
Furnish my bosom with another heart. Exit.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter sir John Woodhamore, master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Woodhamore.
sp.l: I am her keeper; expect here a while,
And I'll prepare her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I'll attend; poor gentlewoman,
Born with more freedom than thou livest, thy parents
Left thee not rich to be a prisoner,
Nay worse, a prey to this hard man, who hath
Sold thee already, for if I obtain
Thy love — I hear 'em coming.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Gentle niece,
Misconstrue not my actions, 'tis my care
Of thee, and to satisfy the duty
I owe to my dead brother, thy kind parent:
I thus restrain thee, thou art young, and canst not.
Being so good thyself, suspect the world
Hath any false men in't; I know there are
Gallants, that study to undo such virgins
As thou art, that will flatter and betray
Thy fortunes to their riot, this unhappiness
I would prevent, and have new found a man,
Into whose arms I may deliver up
The wealth that I am trusted with.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He's welcome: pray what's your business?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: You may understand, partly by what your uncle hath delivered.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You come a-wooing do ye not? Heigho!

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I'll leave you at opportunity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Troth, if you be a good man, be not tedious,
I do not love set speeches nor long praises,
I hope you've made no verses o'my hair,
Acrostics o'my name, I hate them worse
Than witchcraft, or the place I live in: if
You be a suitor, put me out of my pain,
Quickly I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I am one would be your servant.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My servant? what can you do?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I can love you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I cannot help it, 'tis none of my fault.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Your beauty makes me,
Which cannot be without as fair a soul.
I dare believe my eyes, which till this present,
Could never reach more than your face, and that
At too unkind a distance, from your window;
I have inquired your fortune, and lamenting
With loving pity, such a noble creature
Should be confined to narrow limits, come
To bring you freedom, make you mistress of
Your liberty, and myself, if you can think
me worthy of your love: I do not court
Your fortune, but yourself, and if I urge
With too much haste, what great ones might be proud
To expect, after much suit, and that you cannot
Find in your tongue consent, encourage me,
But for the present with one smile.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I cannot,
Unless I counterfeit, I have not smiled
These ten months; if a sigh will pleasure you,
I can afford enough to break your heart,
And yet I live. Walk into the other room,
You'll find an alteration in the air,
And think you come into a mist, which I
Made all with my own sighs, but I would not
Infect you so; you seem an honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Her sorrows help the growth of my affection;
What will she be in peace, that is so lovely
In her distress; I wish you would impose
Something on me, to settle your sad thoughts,
I would embrace a danger, to assure
The quiet of your mind.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Tis in the power
Of one, that would be kind to help me, but —

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Make me that friend.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You may love me too much,
To undertake that task.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Too much I cannot.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O yes, for though I should esteem him dear,
And call him my true friend, that in this storm
Would lend a cord to save me, yet such is
The misery of the employment, he must not
Love me too well that does it.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Be more plain
And let me never hope to be called yours,
If I refuse any command, that may
Or profit, or delight you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I release these hasty
Protestations.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I pray trust me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will, although
Every syllable you speak, makes me suspect,
You will repent this freedom. If you will do
A grateful office to me, in your person ▪
Give this paper to a gentleman.Gives him a letter.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: In the direction
you'll find it, with all necessary circumstance
To meet with him

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: This all: you do not well.
To mock my honest heart with this cheap service.
I was in earnest, when I promised more,
Than carriage of a letter.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you please
To make it then a perfect act of nobleness,
You may take notice, that I long have loved him,
And if you find him cold, in the perusal:
Tell him I had the promise of his faith,
When I gave up my heart, i'th presence of
A thousand angels, that will witness it:
If yet he be not soft to stir up his
Compassion, tell him how I live, and languish,
You may report you saw me weep, I have not
Much more to say, if you will do this favour,
'Twill be an argument of your respect,
I see your resolution cools already.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: 'Tis a severe employment, but I'll do
Something, pray honour me to kiss your hand,
I have not yet deserved to reach your lip:
Content dwell in your bosom.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: What success?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I hope well, some affairs
Call me away. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Good master Yongrave: how do you like this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I shall desire to see him again, my heart
Is light upon sudden, please you uncle
I'll in, and play a lesson o'my lute. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Do what you please, I relish not your air,
That's only sweet to me that profit brings,
There is no music without golden strings.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Was ever maid so miserable in her affection?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Is not my fate as cruel?
Cannot we love him still, and yet be sisters?
I hope we may; the love I bear to him
Shall not destroy my piety to you:
nature hath framed us two in person, but we are both one in heart.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Indeed we are; we are too much one,
And both love one too much, for either to enjoy him.

sp.speaker: Au
sp.l: Say not so, give me a little time and I will try
How I can give him you; I will persuade
My heart to let him go.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Alas poor sister,
Why should you give him me? it is no argument;
Because I came one minute into life
Before you, therefore you should render first
To me, what is so precious to yourself;
Rather let me begin, that was first made
Acquainted to the world, resign to thee,
And make thee happy by enjoying him.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: But do you know the miserable consequence?
For if you love him with that truth, and fervour
You speak of, (As it were a sin in me
Not to believe it,) can you look for less
Than death, to see me mistress of his faith,
And lead in nuptial triumph to the church?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I cannot tell —

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Or if it did not kill you
So soon, I know the sorrow would distract you.
How can I smile to see my sister weep,
Away her eyes, and tell the jarring minutes
With hasty sighs to know herself forsaken?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And can it be, you could do less, that love him
As well as I, to see him made my husband,
Would it not make you melancholy sister,
And oft retire into the dark to weep,
Could you behold us freely kiss, embrace
And go to bed together, remembering that
You gave this friend to me from your own
Heart, and live?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Why let me die then,
Rather than you, I shall perhaps obtain
Some charitable epitaph, to tell
The world, I died to save my sister's life;
'Tis no such thing to die.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: This is again
Our misery, it is not in our power
be resignation, to assure to either
His love, he only must determine it ▪
We cannot guide his passion.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Nor himself
Direct it, as he now appears divided,
May be, it would be fortunate for both,
Would he be more particular.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: That makes
Our flame increase, that he protests he loves
Us both, so equally.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: 'Tis very strange.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Let us then join our argument to persuade him,
To point out one of us to be his bride,
Tother in time, may hope to gain her freedom;
I know not what I say — we both must plead
Against ourselves: see, he is come already.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: The scales are even still, that one had less
Perfection, to make the doubtful balance
Give difference in their value; but I wrong
Their virtues to wish either any want,
That equally incline my soul to love 'em.
Justice I now consent, thou shouldst be blind,
My eyes are but the cause I cannot see,
And will not give my judgement leave to make
Distinction of these two Democritus,
I do allow thy rashness, and confess
Than thou didst rectify thy contemplation
When thou didst lose thy sight. Which of these two
Instruct me love, that tother? both? what fate
Hovers about my choice? Were it not sin
I would be blind, as poet's fancy love,
Into whom now I am transformed, that then
My soul not looking through these glasses, might
With inward speculation aim at her,
That is the happiest, if one can be so.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sir, if we be not troublesome —

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: You cannot.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To interrupt your meditations, we have a suit.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Both? it must needs be granted,

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nor let us suffer in our modesties,
if our request seem strange.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: 'Tis a command,
And I must needs obey; you two divide this empires

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: You prepare; we dispute not
The strangeness of your love, but pity it,
And are so ready in our own affection
To answer your opinion of us both,
That if you can collect, what divide
On two, and place it fairly upon one,
Choose whom you will make happy.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We expect not
Your hasty answer, though we both desire
A swift end to your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I pray stay. Exit.
I would determine now, but cannot — fair ones,
Was ever lover so perplexed? I must resolve.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why how now Frank? what melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why o'my feet:
I was at your lodging to inquire for you,
And here they told me I should find you.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yes,
Here I am lost indeed; prithee excuse my dulness.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What's the matter, come I guess
The cause, which of these gentlewomen is't? I saw 'em ▪

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Didst? and how dost like 'em prithee?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do like 'em so well, that I could wish —

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Which, which of them?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Faith I cannot tell, the worst of 'em both a-bed wi'me.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Thy wishes are
Not modest: couldst thou love one of them nobly?
Ha? thou hast a person and fortune to invite thy
Entertainment, come let me counsel you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: To love, and to a blessing: couldst thou see
So sweet a pair, and feel no burning shaft?
Hast thou a soul about thee, that is capable
Of knowledge and delight? didst ever love?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes once, and I think heartily, for the time,
But I ha' drowned her.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: In sack, I think as gallants lose their mistresses,
By drinking their health too often.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Prithee do not trifle.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What wouldst have me answer? I can love.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: A woman?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What dost make of me?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: With honour?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And honesty, if I see cause.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Enough; thou shalt have cause
Within two minutes, shalt but see again
These sisters, and be proud to be a servant,
I prophesy already; o my friend!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Pray take me wi'you.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yes, thou shalt go with me
And speak to 'em, and be amazed as I am,
To know there are such creatures.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I ha' seen a multitude of fair ones.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: All other women
Are but like pictures in a gallery,
Set off to th'eye, and have no excellency
But in their distance; but these two, far off
Shall tempt thee to just wonder, and drawn near
Can satisfy thy narrowest curiosity:
The stock of woman hath not two more left,
To rival them in graces.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You speak for 'em,
I may go farther, and fare worse, —. I'll not
Consider more on't, let's to 'em, stay —
Which of these two's your mistress? let me know ▪
Where to direct my service.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: That question
Hath puzzled me already.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Say, which is't you best affect ▪

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I love 'em both, so equally,
I know not which to name.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How, both? what then
Should I do with 'em? art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: A little,
Contain thyself, and call thy reason to thee,
Although it be the cruelty of my fate,
I can be no bar to thee; I can enjoy
But one, and yet thou shalt have choice
Of both, thou art not thus my rival,
But my friend, relief of my distraction for she
whom thou refusest, if thou canst endear thyself to either,
In my heart shall meet a clear and perfect entertainment.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Canst thou resolve? win either,
And we both grow happy at once.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You say well, this is fair —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: They are here.

div.stage: Enter simple and m. golds. at one door, and Thump, Chris. and Aurel. at the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: With your favour I must chide you sir, not once speak to my daughter, she expects to be courted with kisses and embraces.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I could kiss her all over, and embrace her too, but I have an imperfediment, I cannot speak as I would do; but let me alone a little, I'll try, let me see, and I ha' not forgotten my verses.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Here they are, I'll not trouble you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will leave this gentleman;
He is my best friend ladies.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: You oblige us more to respect him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I hope you will be just,
At my return, when I declare myself.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir, you sha'not need to urge it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am your honourer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Now Thump, I am resolved to speak to her, whatsoever come on't; hum, hum. Enter Mr. Goldsworth.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What another suitor?
I were best lock up my daughters, they'll be smothered with gentlemen: sir Gervace you are a welcome man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You shall see, if I do not speak to her, now
Now, and to the purpose, in spite of the devil.

sp.speaker: Thump
sp.l: Stroke me o'th back. He plucks aur. by the gown.
There's something in my head, and 'twere out.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: I hope you do not mean your brains.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Would somebody loved me, but as well, as I loved somebody.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Now 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: La you there, I think I talked to her.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: But in my opinion you were quickly daunted.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Was I so? well mark me now, now, I will wink as hard as I can, and then I'm sure she cannot put me out.

div.stage: Sim. takes Cap. by the hand.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Beauty —

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How now? what means this?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Let me but kiss thy hand, and tell
How much I love thee; I know very well
Thou art a phoenix, beauteous and bright,
And dost burn every man for thy delight
Thy eyes are sun and moon, not to be matched.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: This was intended for you sister.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thy hair is fine as gold, thy chin is hatched
With silver, needs must brazen be my face,
That cannot come into thee with a grace.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Before or after meat.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Sweet, hear me out.
But this I know, I am thy faithful lover,
O quench my fire.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Or else the pot runs over.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You're in the right:
Accept me for thy servant, not thy foe,
For I do love thee better than any man in the whole world can do.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Come kiss me then, and open thy fair eyne.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Gentlemen, rest you merry; Thump,
By this hand I'll be drunk presently.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: And you had taken my counsel, you had done so
Before you came hither: wine is armour of proof. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ladies I am sorry, this rude fellow has
Abused your ear, with harsh, and untuned numbers.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Your verses have a tune belike

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I came a purpose, to present a copy
Of verses that should make your genius stand
O'th tiptoe, list to me, and grow immortal.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: We shall be troubled now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If please you lady
We'll walk aside , I have something of more weight
I would impart. Ex.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I'll leave him too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Master Caperwit, before you read, pray tell me,
Have your verses any adjectives?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Adjectives, would you have a poem without
Adjectives? they are the flowers, the grace of all our language:
A well chosen epithet doth give new soul
To fainting poesy, and makes every verse
A bride, with adjectives we bait our lines,
When we do fish for gentlewomen's loves,
And with their sweetness catch the nibbling ear
Of amorous ladies, with the music of
These ravishing nouns, we charm the silken tribe,
And make the gallant melt with apprehension
Of the rare word: I will maintain 't against
A bundle of grammarians, in poetry,
The substantive itself, cannot subsist
Without an adjective.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: But for all that,
Those words would sound more full, methinks , that are not ▪
So larded, and if I might counsel you,
You should compose a sonnet clean without 'em:
A row of stately substantives, would march
Like Switzers, and bear all the field before 'em;
Carry their weight, show fair like deeds enrolled,
Not writs, that are first made, and after filled.
Thence first came up the title of blank verse,
You know sir, what blank signifies? when the sense
First framed, is tied with adjectives like points,
And could not hold together without wedges:
Hang't 'tis pedantic, vulgar poetry,
Let children when they versify, stick here,
And there these piddling words for want of matter:
Poets write masculine numbers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You have given me a pretty hint, 'tis new.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And will be grateful,
My daughter will affect it much the better,
And 'twill be honour, if she be the first,
To whom so choice a poem is presented.
I wish you well sir. Exit ▪

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You oblige my service,
I will bestow these verses o'my footman;
they'll serve a chambermaid, let me see
I want a little quickening, two or three
Infusions of sack will heighten me,
And make my genius dance, than lady, lady — gone?
She's hard of soul, but I must supple her,
And there's a conceit new struck upon my brain
Will do't, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 forces united conquer,
Lady grow soft, if merit cannot prove
Happy, we must use policy in love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No more; you do not well to wrong your friend,
That trusts you with his bosom.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Fair one, hear me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: He gave you welcome hither, and you practise
Unworthily to supplant him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are too
Severe, I have no thought so wicked lady,
Deny me not that liberty, which all
The creatures have, to wish their own felicity;
Which cannot be without you, he will not
Repine to see me happy in your love.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In seeming to extenuate your error,
You thus enlarge it, and bring into question
The honour of your friend, for whom I must
Though weak, rise up a champion for his virtue,
And to beat off all argument, on your part
To move for my affection, know, he is next heaven,
The only object of my heart, nor can it know a change.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And yet if you collect yourself, you are not
The only mistress of his heart, your sister he loves
As well as you; your pardon fairest, 'tis possible,
He may prefer her too, since neither piety nor law allows ▪
He can be husband at one time, to both.
Then let discretion guide you first to freedom,
I love you not with half a heart, but all;
Heaven knows with all, at every look you do
Transfix me, and can only cure the wound
With the same eyes, if they but smile upon it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I must not hear you plead thus, you appear
Nor friend to him, nor me; so fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I am caught, by this good day I am, and know not
How now to help myself: a handsome thing!
What a blind buzzard is this jackanapes Cupid?
Pox of his bird-bolt, I'll not leave her:
Yet I may be too forward; I am punished:
Venus, thy pardon, I beseech thee,
If thou beest not hard-hearted, as the poets feign,
Speak to thy boy to fetch his arrow back,
Or strike her with a sharp one, make her squeak,
And I'll allow thee a goddess. Ha, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Before thou speak'st to me, let me peruse
Thy face, I'll tell myself how thou hast sped:
Well? is't not so? Yet do not answer me,
That smile does not show clear, there is some cloud
Ith' corner of thy forehead, that would spread,
And darken all thy face.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Your physiognomy is quite discredited.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hast prevailed? With which? why now thou art too tedious.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: With the eldest, Chrysolina.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha, what sound was that? With Chrysolina?
I prithee what of her, I love her dear;
Thou hast not filched away her heart, it grew with mine.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hast thou not seen the woodbine,
That honey-dropping tree, and the loved Bryer,
Embrace with their chaste boughs, twisting themselves,
And weaving a green net to catch the birds,
Till it do seem one body, while the flowers
Wantonly run to meet and kiss each other?
So 'twas betwixt us two.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I mean the youngest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What my Aurelia?
Thou canst not rob me so: the amorous turtles
Have but their imitation from our love;
The pelican loves not her young so well,
that digs upon her breast an hundred springs,
When in her blood she baths the innocent birds,
As I do my Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Godbe-wi'y', — I know not how to please you, nor to answer.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Engage me in a business?
Nay, thrust me oth' lime-twigs, to set you
At liberty, when your own wings were glued
Toth' bush, and d'ye reward me at his fashion?
And I had known it, you should ha' fluttered.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I forgotten myself, I prithee pardon me,
I will excuse thee when thou art in love.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Then do so now, and you'll be temperate and hear me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Speak, I am recollected.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: And I am in love.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thou didst name both, thou art so unhappy.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Your humours lead me to't, but I shall tell you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Which, which of them did most encourage thee?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Be not you passionate still, but give me thanks,
And call me fortunate, she has half consented.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I shall be lost ith' dark: declare which.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Which? why the eldest; which? Chrysolina,
Now be you advised, and court the other.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Half consenting.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I may say three quarters, and not lie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis false; and such a stain thou throwest upon that virgin,
Thy blood deserves to purge.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You do not mean to play the fool thus:
Pox upon this madness: I woe not fight with you,
And I will love that gentlewoman:
I thought I had done you a courtesy.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So thou hast, if it be true.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Have you a mind to be the everlasting madcap?
And you can couple with both, I can resign;
Poor gentlewoman, shell ha' the worst on't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But I prithee tell me,
With what art didst thou so soon win her to thee?
It was some months 'Ere I prevailed; and were I not
Confident of thy honesty, I should
Suspect some witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: There is an art
In wooing, not revealed to every man,
Which he that knows, shall do more with a maid
In some minute, than others in a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'T must be a lucky minute.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Ay, he must take her ith' nick; and court her
In the precise minute: yet it may be, she
In pity of my sufferings or mistrusting
She might not be the first in your election,
Inclined the sooner: now would I have you,
Without more ceremony, neglect the wench
That I have choosed: d'ye mark? neglect her,
And address all your courtship to the youngest,
Your meaning will be clearly understood
A both sides; so you shall with ease, enlarge
Your own heart, fix on one whose arms already
Are open to ye, and make my path direct,
Without any rub to the other. Is this sense?
Obey it then; set on afore with your mistress
A hand gallop, if I overtake you not, let me swing
I'th bridle, and set a saddle o'my back, and let all the
Fools in the town ride me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We must not be too rash, let's walk, and think on't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou'rt a brave wench.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You are grown bold of late.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I think so, gramercy sack: come kiss me, wilt thou be a lady?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I have no great ambition.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll buy thee a parrot tomorrow, and a monkey:
Here, take this ring.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Pray keep it, and let me tell you sir my mind.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And I'll tell thee mine, that's one for another.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Briefly then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Be as brief as you please, I can be as brief as you, and tedious too: I know thou lovest me: sirrah, didst think I was such a fearful coxcomb as I made myself? No, I know when to be lion, and when to be a hare. But prithee tell me plainly, when shall we matrimony it, ha? thou dotest upon my good parts; come, speak to me, prithee be not bashful.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I fear you won't understand me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Speak no language, and I warrant, I know Greek and Latin, I learned my accidence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then know, I do not love you, sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You do not love me, sir: then I have lost my labour, sir ▪

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I make no doubt it will appear so,
I could be of the humour of some mistresses,
By some slight favours to encourage you,
Accept your gifts, extol your wit, invent
New ways to melt your gold, beside the exchange,
And petticoat embroideries.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou shalt have smock embroideries; nay, thy very skin shall be embroidered.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Have every day some progress for your coach,
And tire you worse than your four Flanders mares ▪
And then laugh at you too: but I am honest,
And will deserve your nobler character:
I tell you what you must expect, in troth
I cannot love you, pray leave off in time,
And let this satisfy you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: This satisfy? why this is even as good nothing.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It is all that I can promise you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Though you cannot love me,
it shall be for your honour to marry me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What, not marry me neither?
Then be no lady, that I first pronounce:
Secondly know, I am resolved, your mother
Shall understand it, by these hilts.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I would advise you rather to be silent,
And take your leave like a good Christian lover:
If you betray my honest meaning so,
And move her to impatience, I shall wish you
Ith' West Indiaes. Enter mistress golds.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Here she comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Sir I hope, you and my daughter are agreed,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And the conditions please me infinitely;
Mother you never placed your commendation
Upon a gentleman so noble, such
Plenty of honour dwells in him, I must
Be happy in his embraces.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O ho! is't come about again?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Nay nay, I told you, you should find him honourable ▪

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: We understand each other perfectly,
He has so sweet a soul, I may have any thing;
He has promised me the finest parrots.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O ay, and madgehowlets that can speak all languages ▪

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Nay, and he'll perform:
Well, for this act of duty, I shall find
Some gold beside thy portion, i'th mean time
I'll move thy father to conclude the marriage:
And here he is already.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Look you sir,
These turns you put me too; do not believe
I bear one thought more of goodwill for this ▪
If you suspect it otherwise; because
I carry it sweet and pleasing to my mother,
Who is so zealous in your cause, I'll swear
Your worship is the most unwelcom'st man
I'th world to me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'm glad she is not gone yet.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What need you distrust?
He'll know precisely when we must be married,
Is jealous of delays, won't believe I love him,
Till the priest hath sealed me his i'th church, he says.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: These are tricks, demurs, your daughter is not sober.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He means serious.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She doth but mock —

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Who would think you could dissemble.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Sir have patience, I have not been so hasty,
To become tedious at last, refer that to my care;
Since you have made a marriage in your hearts,
The church shall soon confirm it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What do y'think of this?
Faith yet be wise and leave this wooing,
I shall maintain this humour to my mother,
And find a crotchet to come off with honour, you have not
Yet my hate, pray let's be friends, and never meet again,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: This is very fine i'faith, if I do not study some mischief.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Conceal for your own shame.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How d'ye like 'em lady? 'tpleasd your father
To impose somewhat severely on my muse,
But your divine acceptance shall declare it
A crowned poem, most illustrious simple,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Simple me no more than I simple thee.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, there is a lady inquires for master Caperwit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A lady out of compliment? 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: She seems of noble quality, she has coach and fair
Attendants, and calls herself the lady bird.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Good Cupid is it she?
Who gave her direction to find me here?
An honourable lady, I confess, and hath a fortune
Noble like her birth, 'tis the rich alderman's widow,
The great bird that died at's country house, a kinsman
To the ravens of the city; by no means admit her,
She'll betray her foolish passion.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Some few days ago
I did by chance, but drop a compliment,
How much I was her servant, and she took it
To'th heart, and ever since hath sought occasion
To express her love to me, poor gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis one, but of the myriad of ladies
That have been taken —

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: With your tropes and figures,

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: No matter, let her come, it were not civil
Sir to deny yourself.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: She'll tire all patience ▪
But lady, be assured my heart is dedicate
To you, and were all women kind in balance
With your divinest person, their light scale
Would kick the firmament, or coming down,
Be lost i'th middle region of the air,
Or be converted to a cloud to weep
Upon the earth, for being so much excelled.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Where's this footman?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Trot my lady's footman,

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Go pray my uncle sir Walter cormorant
To dine with me tomorrow — and do y'hear?
'Tis in your way to ask if my cousin Bulfinch,
The steward of my land, be come to town,
He lies in Fleetstreet between hawk and buzzard.
I'th afternoon, remember sirrah, that
You go to master kite, that lives i'th poultry,
And say I shall expect the thousand pound,
Was lent him upon mortgage:
Sir, beseech your nobleness excuse me,
The affairs so nearly do concern me, with
A gentleman, (Now your guest,) that I presumed
It should not be offence, if I took hold
Of this occasion, to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Madam, you need plead no excuse for that,
Command your freedom here: daughters, my lady
Would have some private conference,

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: By no means
Let me appear so troublesome, your presence
will be no hurt to my design, you shall
Command a great deal more.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Twas cunningly prepared,

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: Sir, after all, let me obtain your privilege.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Proceed. —

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: I shall accuse myself of too much boldness,
If you neglect me sir before all these;
I come not to disturb you, nor to publish
What you have taken from me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I hope she will lay some felony to his charge.

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.p: But sir, you might have been so kind, to have seen your friend once in three days.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I must be pardoned widow,
The glass that tells the hour, hath not more sands,
Than there be ladies wait to catch me up
To spend my time with 'em, they break my dreams,
With importunity, and allow me but
One minute in a week, to say my prayers.

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: Among them all, there is not one
That more desires your happiness.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Tis more your goodness lady, than desert,
Or provocation in me.

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: You're modest,
And thus increase your value.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Your favours are acknowledged, and take up
Much of my studies, how I may be active
In service to reward 'em, still preserving
My liberty, I must not be confined
Or wedged in; all that's good in nature ought
To be communicable, if you have
Promised yourself more of me, than as you are
Allowed, an excellent part o'th commonwealth,
'Tis justice you correct the imagination,
Perhaps you'll say, you love me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: A fine dialogue:

sp.speaker: Bi.
sp.l: My blushes speak me guilty, and I fear
Betray my frailty to these gentlewomen:
You'll sin against your knowledge sir, to make
A question how much I esteem you, be not
A tyrant, if my opinion of your worth
prevail against my modesty, to say
I cannot choose but love you, 'tis my fate,
My breeding never suffered, but in this,
That I should lose myself to court a man,
Ambitious of my favour; 'tis in vain
To tell you, with what art, my eyes have been
Courted by great ones for their smile, for you
Will turn them all to tears.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Alas poor lady ▪
I pity her, what doth she see in him,
To draw this passion?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: May be, I am engaged
To another beauty.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: That's my fear indeed;
For who can look with eyes like mine upon you,
And not be tempted to the same desires?
But be not sir deceived, all foreheads are not
True glasses of the mind, and beauty alone
Deserves not such a blessing ▪ young men do
Too hastily betray themselves to misery,
That think no heaven but in their mistress face,
Look on my fortune, which doth spread more riches,
Than pleasure can instruct thee ways to spend,
Delights shall stream themselves into thy bosom,
Honour and titles of the state shall woe
Thy name to put them on and not be thine
But thou their ornament.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Affection must
Flow uncompelled, you may be pleased to take
Some other time to finish this discourse.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I may suspect I have offended these;
But pray interpret fairly, noble sir,To simple.
I do beseech you pardon
The errors that you find in us frail women,
Yet I believe you would not use me so
Neglectfully: 'tis time, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: We are your humble servants.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Sir, if you will not affect this lady,
I hope some other may.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: And write himself the happiest man alive;
She is widow for a lord; but I am fixed,
I would you had her sir, I say no more;
She has an estate of twenty exchequers, and ▪
Is of so gentle soul.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I leave you to repent
Your cruelty, my coach —

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Please you madam,
Do me the grace to let me wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Now do I expect she'll dote upon me:Ex. Gol. bird, simple.
Ladies, you see what fortunes I neglect,
She is a pretty handsome creature too.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: In my opinion sir, you have not been
So kind as she deserves, and for my part
I have so much compassion of her sufferings,
Were all the wit of younger brothers in you,
And could you make me jointure of a province,
I would rather marry my father's serving man
And stand at livery myself than be
Wife to a man so ingrateful. Ex. Au.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How, sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: My sister, sir, is just, can you expect
An entertainment here after your scorn
Of one that nobly loves you? Ex. Chr.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I have used a precious policy to supplant myself,
She has a scruple in her conscience,
And will not wrong the lady bird, a pox
Upon his rhetoric.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Your lady bird is coached, and she hath taken
Sir Gervace with her.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Their legs do justice
In the same boot.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Why do you laugh? What humour's this?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir Gervace: ha, ha, he thinks, ha, ha —

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You have a merry spleen, I know not what
He thinks, but if he mean to retrieve the lady bird.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Pray let me know, whence springs this sudden mirth; I will laugh wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Hold my sides, my buttons!

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: 'Tis well your doublet's slashed

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ha, ha, next time I come, I'll discover — I sha'not
Contain myself i'th' street, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: The poet's mad indeed, farewell Democritus. Ex.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: By your favour sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Your business?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I understand your name is Thornay.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: It was my fathers, and 'tis, upon record, that I was christened Thomas, does that concern you sir?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: I bring commends from a friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I crave you mercy,
I am your servant. Reads the letter ▪

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: He appears unmoved.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thank you sir, godbe-wi'y'.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Although I am confident
You think it not my office to convey
Letters so much respect I bear the gentlewoman
That sent it, I would think it sir no burden
To carry an answer to her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: It requires none.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Shall I return, you'll visit her in person?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I cannot promise.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I may forget it.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: With your pardon sir, she did impose on me.
To know some resolution.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: She did?
Are you acquainted with her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I do bear
No great age in her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Perhaps she has imparted the contents.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I could conjecture
By circumstance she much desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Cannot come; that's all —

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I must have more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: 'Tis a neglect becomes you not.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are not sent a champion to defy me.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I have no title from her blood, and yet
Her virtue is so near me, I must tell you,
She hath deserved your best esteem.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: She has told you belike some story.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I pray see her, I'll wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: To what purpose?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: To love and cherish her, that claims your heart,
The office of your soul to honour her,
Does not your conscience tremble yet? what reason
Can you allege you should not love her?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Reason? I'll show you a reason, walk a little further.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I shall expect it. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It must be so, and yet methinks I move
Without a soul, she is the first apostate
From love's religion, in that my honour
Is safe, and it is justice, my Aurelia,
This heart to thee, should now alone be sacred.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Sir, you are welcome, what not speak to me?
This is a strange neglect; I have news for you:
Your friend —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis so, he has prevailed with her,
And she will boast her change.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: He cannot be
So fixed in meditation; with your favour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Reserve your news, I do not thirst to hear it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Sure he mistakes me all this while, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: But 'tis not I, I see you are a woman,
I have nothing else to say. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.p: I have not used him so: was there no way to express his purpose, without this scorn? 'tis not discreetly done, I could be very angry he returns,Enter Gerard; Aurelia.with him Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am ignorant
With what words I should meet this noble love.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I was created for this happiness,
To these embraces which do more than twist
Our bodies, every circle of thy arms
Enchains my soul, that doth forget all freedom,
And willingly submit to be thy prisoner.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It do not grieve me that he loves my sister,

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I am too little to contain my joy,
It flows above the narrow banks Aurelia:
What shall I say let me bathe here eternally,
and study new arithmetic, to count
Our blessings.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Can you sir be constant?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ay, touch him there Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You do ill
To interrupt our joys upon this lip
That deserves all should open to commend it,
I seal the contract of my heart for ever,
I will be nothing when I am not thine:
Suspect the stars may lose themselves in heaven,
But never I this vow, thy sister has
No part in my affection; she usurped
Some title, but I now have cancelled all
The thoughts of her, and offer thee myself,
Myself thy perfect honourer. Ex. Ger. Aur.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Wherein have I deserved to be thus slighted?
Is there no conflict in my blood? Can love
I bear a sister, take away all sense
Of this indignity?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Look you sir, I promised you a reason, why I could
Not love Eugenia; there's my reason, I
Do love that gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: 'Tis master Thornay:
I am resolved, I have no other way
To punish his disdain, than to pretend
I love this gentleman, that he may see
I have the freedom of my soul, to mock
His triumph, and with as much facility
Meet his neglect. O master Thornay,
You are very welcome, I was wishing for you.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Hum? this entertainment is a little better
Than I expected.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You absent yourself too much believe, your visits shall not be more frequent, than your person grateful hither.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Do y' hear, you may return, and tell this story
Unto the lady i'th enchanted castle:
You see my fate, I cannot come; godbe-wi'y'.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You shall acquit yourself more nobly sir,
and better satisfy her in your person.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I won't take the pains to see her, and
She were a dying.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Not to recover her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Shall you and I sir, walk a turn i'th garden.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Yes lady, heaven vouchsafe I grow not mad
Wi' my good fortune.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: With your pardon mistress,
I must take privilege to tell this man
He is not worthy of your favours.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: How sir?
You do not know my temper:

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Nor regard it.Draw.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Hold as you bear respect to me.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I am charmed.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I should be guilty of some sin to you
Not to reveal, this gentleman has made
A forfeit of his honour.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Will you hear him?
Pox o'my dulness, what meant I to bring
Him hither? do not credit any thing,
We are old enemies, and he has studied this
Device to poison your opinion of me,
A mere trick; do not believe a word sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I am not easy sir to entertain
Malicious accusation of your fame,
Your virtue in my thoughts, is not so soon
Shaken with one report.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: That's comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Then you provoke me to be plain, know lady,
You're i'th way to be most miserable,
Abused by this false man, that will betray
Your innocent beauty to so great a shame,
Repentance is not able to restore you:
He has a wife already.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: How a wife?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: A wife, if holy vows have power to bind you:

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Do you believe this? were you by
When I was married.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: No, but heaven and angels
Are witnesses you did exchange a faith
With one that mourns a virgin, and a widow:
have you no earthquake in you? does thy soul
Itself not feel an ague, to remember
How many kisses sealed the amorous contract?
She meant it so, and every day her eyes
Weep in the memory of herself forsaken:
And cause her grief will not at once destroy her,
Despairing of your love, to show how willing
She is to die, doth every hour distil
Part of her soul in tears.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This cannot be.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Be: no, no, 'tis impossible: shall we walk sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Will not this excite your pity, mercy shines bright in women.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I have heard you sir,
And doubt not, when he comes to answer
These imputations, he may quit himself.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Would we were both on's but to skirmish in
A saw-pit, I must cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Admit he promised love,
Obliged himself by oath to her you plead for,
This binds him not to undo himself for ever.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Undo himself.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Yes, marriage is an act,
That doth concern his whole life, and in something
May mar, or profit his eternity:
Perhaps the gentlewoman, since he gave
His faith is fallen from virtue.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I have heard so.

sp.speaker: Chr
sp.l: May be turned prostitute.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Ay, who'll swear for her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I must not hear her named with the suspicion
Of such a stain.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: We do not sir accuse her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Not absolutely.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Did you but know the creature, it would call
A blush into your face, for talking thus;
She has purity enough for all her sex,
And this attended with so many virtues,
As but to wish her more, itself were sin.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This gentleman pleads for her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Will you please to walk?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Dismiss him first.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Do y' hear; this lady
Is weary of your company; you have
Not used me like a gentleman, indeed
Scurvily, 'tis no time nor place to expostulate,
But we shall meet again; in the mean time,
Return, and tell the virgin you so magnify,
I do not find myself in any humour
To see her again; pray her neglect no fortune,
For my sake, there be many younger brothers
I'th town, will be content to marry her:
You may resolve her what's become of me,
There is no wrestling with our fate.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Thou art not worth my answer. Exit Yon.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I'll not question sir, this gentleman's relation.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are wise.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But in my confidence, he hath spoke all truth:
I must desire you visit me no more.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You do but jest I hope.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ingrateful man! how are poor women cozened?
With what impudence couldst thou desire my favour?
Go and make a satisfaction to the injured maid,
Born the dishonour of a man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Am I awake? Or do I dream,
I am made a coxcomb thus?
I am a rascal, and deserve no mercy,
For abusing that poor gentlewoman, that sent
So kindly to me; would the messenger were here again.
'Tis master Gerard, how hath he sped?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You are sad Aurelia; what on the sudden
Can beget this change? Are you in health?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your blood methinks
Is wand'ring from your cheek, your eyes have lost
Their lightning too, call back your smiles, and bless
Him that is now your creature.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Mine? excuse me if I suspect.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I have heard you sir.
And have considered all that you have said
To make me think you are now wholly mine:
I must confess you have expressed a lover,
Wanted no art to flourish your warm passion:
But language is no clew to guide us to
The knowledge of your heart.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Nor is suspicion a cause enough in justice to condemn.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It is not; but where circumstances meet,
They may be thought on.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: By your beauty,
By those fair eyes, that never killed till now,
Make me so happy, but to know what cause
Inclines you to suspect, and I will take it
The greatest argument of love, that ever
A virgin showed to man; then I'll be bold,
And with the whiteness of my soul make such
Assurance of you, that not malice, aided
With all the devils cunning, shall be able
To interpose one scruple more against me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You loved my sister.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I did once, my Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And you declare you can neglect her now,
Look on her like a stranger.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis most true.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She loved you well, most nobly, with as much
Fervour as ever I did or can love;
Should I think to be more secure than she?
Promise that firm to me, which in so fresh
A sight and memory you have violated
To her, that placed you in as dear a bosom?
Discretion bids me pause, I may be rash,
Either you loved her not at all, and so
You may play false with both, or loving her
With as much levity, I suppose you may
Forsake me too. Therefore I bid you first farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I am blasted.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: We are both undone, I dare not see him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Was ever man so miserably lost?
Is there a balm can cure me? O, I bleed:
The sword wounds gently but love kills indeed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Has truth forsook mankind? or is it my
Fate only to converse with those that are
So cruel and neglectful of our sex?
Unhappy maid is he not yet returned?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: None yet appears.

lg.l: Then I despair to see him:
And when I think indeed of the employment,
That 'tis against himself, I may with justice
Accuse my want of judgement, to expect
He should perform so hard an imposition:
I would I could not think of any man,
They rob me of my peace: I prithee try
Thy voice, to put my heart in better tune;
There is a power in harmony, some say,
To charm the unruly motions of the brain:
Love is itself a melancholy madness:
Why should not music cure the wound of love?
Melancholy hence, go get
Some piece of earth to be thy seat,
Here the air and nimble fire,
Would shoot up to meet desire:
Sullen humour, leave her blood,
Mix not with the purer flood,
But let pleasures swelling there,
Make a springtide all the year.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: How does my dear Eugenia?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: As well
As this restraint will give me leave, and yet
it does appear a part of my enlargement
To have your company: I hope your sister
Enjoys her health.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: And more felicity
Than I can boast mine own, she's half a bride.
Happy ith' embraces of her wished servant;
You know our story; he has chosen her,
And most uncivilly neglecteth me.
Thus laden with his scorn, I come to practise
A scene of sorrow w'ye; sure thy fate
Hath spun a thread for me, we are so like
In our misfortunes: have you heard no new ▪
Of your ingrateful servant, for I know
No other name, and he indeed deserves
To have no other memory ▪ that takes
A pride in his disdain.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nothing as yet.
But I have met occasion to convey
A letter to him, yet I cannot promise:
But here's the messenger.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: That gentleman?
I know the man you love then, is't not Thornay?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: The same, I did conceal him for his shame.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Why he's a zealous suitor for my love.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: It makes for me that he continues cruel;
I was not able to command his passion.
But will she not mistrust I have not been
So careful in advancing her desires,
But satisfied myself with any answer,
As knowing what must bring comfort to her,
Must needs be killing to my hopes? In what
A narrow path I tread; her spring must be
My frost, and when her tree carries the pride
And bloom of summer, I retain no sap,
But wither and creep backward into earth,
Like a forsaken plant.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Here I'll obscure. Chrysolina withdraws.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I would I were.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Shall I believe you have been faithful to
my grief's request?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Yes, and bring comfort back.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Pronounce those words again.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He did say so: what meant she
To mock me with another sad relation?
Was't a device in her to increase my joy
