At meeting, he did talk of comfort; is it
A thing restored in nature? O, before
You bless my ear again with that wished sound,
Excuse my modesty, if my heart present
A kiss to thank you.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I drink in my poison.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now let your comforts flow.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I have returned you
As true a lover as yet ever mistress
Could boast possession of, one so resolved
To honour you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Can this be possible?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I have examined every secret thought
Within his foul, concerning you, and dare
Thus boldly justify, he is your own.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Let me but live to see him, and I write
My ambition satisfied

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: He's here.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Here,
In me your truest servant is returned.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Does he affect her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I call all that's good
To witness with me, I discharged with zeal
The unkind office to myself, but could not
Incline him to return to any softness:
In brief, he has unworthily engaged
That heart belonging to you, and would not be
Provoked to see you again.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Eugenia. Chr. leads in Eug.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Is all this waking? Have I seen her faint?
And did not she that cherishes her enemy,
Haste to her relief, and seem to suffer with her?
While I, as one had grown here, did not move?
I did not well, to exalt her with a hope:
To meet a blessing, and then ruin her.
If death hath whispered her aside, I shall
Be accused, and I will take my preferment
to be sent after her to tell her ghost
I loved her best; when we are both immortal
She'll understand me better.
Is Eugenia alive again?

sp.speaker: Chr,
sp.l: There is no danger to be feared; a qualm.
Pray let me ask you sir one question,
Do you affect this virgin really?
I move it not for any harm.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Would she had sent hither,
But with desire to be resolved.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: May be she has.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Then tell her I do love her better
Than I can express, but when she has
Numbered all things are excellent on earth
She is to me above 'em infinitely.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This carries no probability.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Would thou wert a man
Than I durst tell thee, I do love her so
I durst be wicked for her, and kill thee.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: With all this, it does not appear you love her so
And be an instrument, nay plead to put another in possession
Of your loved treasure; for if I mistake not
You late did urge a man, whom she esteemed
Better, to return and marry her:
Can any man that loves a woman truly,
Strive to supplant himself and give away
His comfort?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: There's the honour of my service,
When I am dead, the story shall remember
I loved a maid so well that I preferred
Whatever she desired above myself,
And cause she loved one better, was content,
To serve her wishes with my banishment:
He does not love a virgin nobly, whose
Affection walks not just to her desires,
To like 'em 'bove his own.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: If this can be,
Thou art the noblest lover in the world,
with what affection shall she be blessed
That loves him, when the mistress that esteems
Him not, is thus rewarded?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Indeed I love him still and shall do ever,
Nor had I now returned to life, but that
I had not took my leave of him

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: More corrosive.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you'll oblige a virgin,
For ever to you once more visit him,
Tell him I lie like one that's desperate sick,
Oppressed with grief of body, and of mind,
But cannot be so fortunate to quit
The world till he vouchsafe to visit me.
Bid him not fear I will detain him long ▪
With idle talk, six words and I am dead.
Although he love me not, he may do this:
If you will add this to your other work,
I will impose no more, indeed I will not:
So farewell noble sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: If you will please to join with me, I doubt not
To effect her wishes.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: You do not know what power I have with him.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You have too much

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I'll undertake —

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You sha'not rob me of the reward.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: What reward?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Perhaps another kiss; pray tell her, I
Went cheerfully to finish her command. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I do admire and love this noble temper,
What flames are these? Suppress 'em, they grow high,
If he affect her so, what hope have I? Ex.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Mad? why you still enjoy discourse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What then? may not a man be mad, and yet talk wisely?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: But few in my experience.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Do not abuse thy knowledge, at the worst ▪
Thou canst but say, our senses are depraved,
Thrown off o'th' hinge; the tongue is none I hope,
though some would have the titillation
Joined to make up a sixth in the grave synod:
Believe then I am mad; I'll prove't by reason.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: By reason? that's a new way to prove it;
But I'll hear no reason.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then thou art mad thyself.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Nay, I think I am madder o'th two,
And have as much reason, if there be reason
Able to make one mad; but let's be wise:
Or if it must be that you've lost your wits,
Let's see and we can recover 'em by drinking;
For he that is not sober after drunkenness,
Is no man of this world.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now thou talkest wildly.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: I talk wildly, that would justify myself to be in my wits, and you that talk reason and sense won't believe you've any.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: If it be so, that may conclude I ha' lost 'em,
And do not understand myself.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: So, so, I should believe another in that argument,
But not you, for in knowing that, you prove
You are no madman.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Prithee tell me, thou art a piece of a philosopher,
And knowest the natural causes.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Hold in that; I must confess, you are little
Beside yourself: I a philosopher?
I studied titleman sometimes i'th college,
As others did, and wanting Epictetus'
Lantern, slept always with a watching candle
In my study window, and might very well
Dream over learning o'my desk, or so;
What Aristotle might infuse into
My sleeps I know not, but waking I ne'er troubled
Myself to understand him; true I loved
His book de coelo, for the heavenly title,
And made my father buy it, for my study
Of divinity, told him I would be a Bishop;
That brought me threescore pound a year for sack:
I prithee do not talk of learning.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Why then acknowledge, I am mad, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Well for this once I will allow it, thou'rt mad.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But wherefore do y'allow it, what's the cause?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I know not that.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I'll tell thee then.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: 'Tis come about again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And let thy judgement censure me
If I produce not able reasons —

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: To prove madness, he makes me mad to hear him;
Now I consider better on't, I confess
You have some cause to be a little mad,
The loss of such a mistress.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But of one?
Did they not both affect me, and I them
With such equality of honour.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Grant it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And I to lose 'em both? faith speak but honestly;
Is't not a wonder that I do not rave
And kill myself? how many have run mad
For one that never loved 'em? and shall I
Be so unmannerly not to lose my wits
For two and two such creatures? 'twere a solecism
In love: I prithee do not flatter me
With an opinion that I have my reason;
It cannot be, it is against all sense,
I should have any; such an expectation
Lost, is enough to make the genius
Of all the world run mad, and I will straight.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To bedlam, whether should I go?
I must not live in this community of fools and wise-men.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: There be knaves among us.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Here all are happy, there I sha'not meet
With lovers that are fortunate, but with men
Of my complexion, that look twenty ways
At once, that sigh and curse, and sing mad carols:
If I can get to be their prince, I'll make
A law it shall be death to smile or kiss
A woman.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Now I fear him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Nay, we'll have
An excellent well governed common wealth,
a delicate Eutopia, there shall be
Lectures and public readings shall put down
Gressam's foundation for the liberal arts,
And make the citizens bring their shop-books hither
To take fine notes, how to be paid their debts,
And yet trust none but younger brothers: than
We will have penal statutes against eating,
Live all by the air of commendations.
No idle man shall live within our state:
Do y' mark? they are the mouths of the republic:
And therefore he that has no other work
To prevent slothfulness, may employ his time
In picking straws, there will be a great plenty.
Here will we live together, and be mad
Perpetually, we won't be recovered;
For if at any time we incline to be
Sober, and coming to our wits again,
The lash will whip us into new distempers
And mad fugaries.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Do y' know all this while
What you have said, you correct me for speaking
Extravagantly, and yet talk wild yourself.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I prithee pardon and instruct me better; I am not well.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Will you walk to your chamber, I'll bear you company.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No, I am well again.
Upon condition you will tell Aurelia
She did not use me kindly.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: She did not use me kindly, nothing else, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I know not what to think on him,
The unhappiness was so sudden, and unlooked for,
It might disturb his fancy, but I hope
The worst is past, a little rest will settle him.
But which way shall I recompense the injury:
I ha' done him? and I had not been ungrateful
To Eugenia, we might have both been happy.
Ha? 'tis he: save you most noble sir;
If't please you now, I'll go along with you
toth' gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: What gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Eugenia, that wrote the letter to me, I mean her.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I ha' considered better, and do mean
To make her satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: 'Tis too late:
You might have done this earlier, your love
Will appear now unseasonable, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Pray give me a reason.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: D'ye not blush to ask it?
I told her what you said, and now we are
Resolved; you cannot blame her, she was covetous
To embrace you; but your answer being returned
So peremptorily in her neglect, we both agreed.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You both? Why what was that to you?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: That doubt will clear itself when we are married.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, did you love her?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: And deserve her best
Of all the world: and yet she'd give me no
Assurance till she knew your resolution,
Which I was able to inform her, and
'Tis now a bargain; upon Monday next. —

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Your wedding day.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: In very good time. You wear a sword.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I'll only try how you can fence, I must not lose her so.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You lose her? you despised her, would not see her,
Not to recover her from death. D'ye not
Remember such a saying, in the town
Were many younger brothers, that might be
Content to marry her; let her use her fortune,
For your own part, you were engaged, there was
No wrestling with your fate: was it not so?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: 'Tis all one for that, my mind is altered,
I'm of another humour now, and will
Maintain, I love her better than you dare.

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Then I must tell you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Tell me no tellings:
Either resign her to me again, or —

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Resolve me, pray, can you affect her heartily?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Else let me perish on your sword.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I heard
you court another mistress, that did answer it with entertainment.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: She was a very Gipsy.
You were no sooner parted, but she used me
Basely; 'tis true, I did sufficiently
Deserve it, for my breach of vow to her
I now alone do honour, and for whom,
(Changed into honesty) I will rather die
Than live without her.

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Heaven does hear all this.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I make no doubt, and while my heart to her
Is reconciled, cannot despair of mercy.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You shall have her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Shall I? then I'll love thee too.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: And know, she has no thought but to be yours,
There has no obligation passed betwixt us two:
I came for this: yet I must tell you, sir,
I love her too, and shall do ever.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: How? not when
She is my wife, I hope.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Yes then.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: If you have cut her up, and left her cold meat,
I shall lose my stomach.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: With a holy flame,
Her virtue keeps a vestal fire within me,
But she affects not me, yet I might challenge her:
Nor can you ever, but in right of me,
Glory yourself possessed; I have bought her.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I hope she has not sold her maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Yo.
sp.l: Her uncle
(Whose aim is only profit) hath concluded
With me a price for her, and therefore gives
Access to none, till I ha' proved my fortune;
But I find her devoted to you only,
And have conformed my wishes unto hers;
She loves you best, and I prefer you too,
Return, and be her husband, I'll direct you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You understand my purpose, you shall make
The dance, let me alone to write the songs.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: A mask will be delightful to the ladies.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O sir, what plays are taking without these
Pretty devices? Many gentlemen
Are not, as in the days of understanding.
Now satisfied without a jig, which since
They cannot, with their honour, call for, after
The play, they look to be served up ith' middle:
Your dance is the best language of some comedies,
And footing runs away with all; a scene
Expressed with life of art, and squared to nature,
Is dull and phlegmatic poetry.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Enough;
I am bound to honour thee, command my life,
Thou excellent young man.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I wish you happiness and never after her will love a woman.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You know my lodging.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I'll attend you sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I wonder what's become of my hermaphrodite?
Yongrave, how is't man? what art melancholy?
What hath hung plummets on thy nimble soul,
What sleepy rod hath charmed thy mounting spirit?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Prithee enjoy thyself.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: By Parnassus
You must not be so head hung, why dost peep —
Under thy cloak as thou didst fear a sergeant?
Who are these? my wish! fortune hath sent thee a cure,
The rarest mirth! you sha'not lose it, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: You have strangely won me to obey you sir,
I refuse nothing you command.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Shalt go,
And hear how I will talk, and baffle 'em:
But what if we meet Caperwit?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No: why then let him go hang himself in his own verses, if the lines be strong enough, come my nightingale, my bird of paradise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: If ever thou didst love me, let's follow 'em;
Feed not this sullen humour, I'll promise excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You shall prevail. Ex.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It was not kindly done, believe me sister,
He did perform but our request.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis granted;
But his neglect of you afflicted me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: He could not make you happy, and remain
servant to me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nor make me blessed, while you
Seemed discontented.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Do not think I was,
I did but carry trouble in my face,
When he declared himself withdrew my smiles,
For your sake, to make you appear most lovely,
And worthy of his choice; and could you be
So cruel to reject him, when he came
To be confirmed your own without a rival?
It seems he did not know who loved him best.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Best?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Yes, and I in this, will make't appear,
That now you have exiled him from your love,
I'll sue for his affection.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He is mine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But you Aurelia are not his; I will
Appeal to his modest reason, that shall guide
His eye to look on both again, I do not
See what in me should not invite him hither,
With as much ardour, rather more, since he
Hath proved already your too much unkindness;
What if this noble gentleman should lose
His wits upon 't, will all your beauty call
His straggling senses to their seat again?
I'll seek him out betimes and comfort him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis more than will become you sister.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And it must bring your modesty in question,
To follow one that cares not for you

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Thus
I may awake his noble flame, nor is it
Any dishonour when the world shall know
How you have used him, if I make return,
To what I loved so dear.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not while I may challenge interest; here are company
sp.stage: Enter simple, bird, Yongrave, Caperwit aloof.
sp.l: Let us withdraw, I have something more to tell you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Defer it rather now; here comes my hope.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How's this? nay then I'll stay a little longer.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By your leave gentlewomen, I should mock you
To call you ladies; perhaps you may wonder at me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I see no cause.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Have you no eyes?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Such as you see?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O eyes no eyes but mountains fraught with tears!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: He's turned Jeronymo.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Go by, Jeronymo, go by, go by. He passeth by them with disdain.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Do y' know where you are?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes, and to whom I speak I hope.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Noble sir, I hope you do not scorn us.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Scorn you, no; but I do not care a rush for you, you might have had me when I was offered, 'tis none of my fault, and you do fall to eating of chalk, and die oth' black jaundice, I cannot help it now for I proclaim, here is the what do y' call it, of my heart.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Has he won this lady? I suspect her:
I hope you have not quite forsaken me;
Virgins for custom's sake, sometimes deny,
Believe me sir, when you did plead for love
My heart did not so much as think on't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay 'tis no matter, I ha' taken my course, yet I
Have a suit to you that you would not break your heart,
Nor you, to see us kiss. Nectar! immortal nectar! He kisses bird.
O let this diamond purchase such another,
'Tis pity that my lips should ever open,
To let the breath she gave me, out again.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Do y' pay so much for every kiss? A diamond?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I never offer less to touch her lip; marry her hand, or her a — or foot or so, I may salute for a ruby, or an emerald or a satire; or so, but I have stones — now do thou speak a little for their further mortification.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I did not think to have returned so soon
A trouble to you but the importunity
Of this most worthy gentleman prevailed,
I think there was some magic in his tongue.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay you may swear that, the wisest in the country, thought my mother a witch.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: He did no sooner open his desires,
But he did wound my heart, you see his bounty,
what jewels he has given me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: All thine own; somebody else might ha' been wise and had 'em.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Somebody else might have been wise, and kept 'em.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I must confess, I loved another lately, but his affection's frozen up —

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Bless you bevy of ladies.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Sir, you are come most seasonably, before
These gentlewomen, I release your promise,
My thoughts are fixed upon this noble knight,
Affect now where you please; here is my husband.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You are not married?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No, but I came to bid you all to my wedding, I have
Bespoke gloves, and points, and knacks, and knaveries.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will dye Hymen's saffron robe in blood,
Put out the torches with the tears of virgins,
And make the temple quake.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Will you so sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Excellent rascal!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: There is no way but to acknowledge it,
It is no shame in love, there's no disgrace,
For else by law he may recover me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Do y' hear sir, you may take her if you please, but if she be troubled with a timpany, there is a man within a mile of an oak, I name nobody, that has had, — some earnest of her body.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I hope you do but jest.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll make all sure; what a loving lady is this?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Then I require you give me back this diamond,
The token once I gave of my devotion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Why that's mine, I gave it her but now before all this company.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: Be wise and let him have it, 'tis like his within my cabinet, let's be quit on him, ▪ this will secure our marriage.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Let him have it there be more in Cheapside, but let's not tarry any longer bird, he'll challenge all the rest of thy feathers.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: I will obey you sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Farewell beauties and kind gentleman, if you come to my wedding, I name no time, nor place, we'll be very merry, excellent cheer I'll promise you, your belly full of fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha, ha. Exit Sim. and Bir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What did you mean? that ring was his.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: The boy shall have't again: ha, ha, you do not know the mystery, this lady is a boy, a very crackrope boy.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I made him first disguise himself.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes faith, to come to you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then I must tell you sir, you have not used us civilly, to make our conversation ridiculous, to talk and compliment with a boy.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sweet lady, by Hippocrene —

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Do y'not think your wit found out a precious device to make me love you by a precedent; is this your great lady?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Do but hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not now, I know you have art enough to excuse it,
Yet I am not merciless, let me entreat
Your absence, without ceremony, when
You come again, your talk will be more musical.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Does she not prophesy the conceit, I go
The mask will do't, more musical? 'tis so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Then he's gone to her

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: He did promise me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Let other virgins when they hear this story
Wonder, but give me leave to love you for it,
Indeed I do; look not so strange, your virtue
Compels me to reveal it, 'tis no shame
To own a passion, kindled by such goodness.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: If I do understand you, give me pardon,
To think you are not perfectly advised;
I am a prisoner still to my Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: She is satisfied, and you are disengaged.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: But she has not yet resigned the heart I gave,
Nor can I think of any other mistress;
Choose in a plenty of more happy men,
I gave too much away to love again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I will retire to blush and weep.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not so.
Alas poor sister, now I fear you not,
I see your purpose was to make me kind:
I would he were my brother, but let's in
And join our heads, some counsel would do well,
'Tis pity we two should lead apes in hell. Exit.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: May I believe myself so fortunate?
Art thou returned, or do I dream thus happily?
Are these my Thorney's arms? are those his lips?
Can he repent his cruelty and love?
How soon are all my tears dried up? I do
Forgive my griefs, and think they have been modest,
And gentle sufferings, who can merit such
A joy, that has not felt a world of sorrow?
Let us embrace again, and if thou canst
Confirm me yet more, that I am awake,
And taste my true delight.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: By this, and this:Kisses.
Through which, if it were possible, I durst
Convey my soul, I am for ever thine,
Created new to be made worthy of thee,
I have been dead too long to thee, and virtue,
Committed sin enough, in my neglect
Of thee, to plant a fierce, and deep antipathy
In every woman's heart against mankind ▪
But you are merciful, and imitate
The eternal nature.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Ha? how is this? A kissing?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: We are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: So now 'tis done; I would not
Be engaged to kiss you again, for all the estate.
Your father left you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I hope my breath has not offended you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I ha' not kissed a woman this twelvemonth, and had not done this, but that he had my oath to perform it; well you have the lip labour he sent you, master Yongrave is well, will see you again shortly — godbe-wi'y'.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You'll send him such another token; employ your waiting woman, I am no common kiss-carrier.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.p: O ho, is't not otherwise, he is a messenger from master Yongrave, you're welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And I be not, I am going sir, to the place from whence I came sir?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.p: How does master Yongrave?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: As foolish as ever, he is still in love —

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.p: I pray commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You may now commend yourself, he is here.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O let me fly into his arms and boast
Never had woman such a noble servant,
Blessed was that minute uncle, in which you
First knew this gentleman; more blessed I,
That do enjoy by him, that which my heart
Next heaven affecteth most; 'twill be an age
Till holy church confirms our vows, I cannot ▪
Manage the comforts you have given me,
I did not think I should so soon have met
A husband, uncle.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Command thy truest servant, nothing wants
But how to get her forth, 'twere soon dispatched.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Sir, we resolve not to lose any time,
We'll marry instantly.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: The licence will be at church, as soon as we,
Than I shall quickly make you perfect owner,
Of all those lands, that lie so near your lordship;
You have security, I shall perform
When we are man and wise.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Right, master Yongrave ▪
You are an honest gentleman, my niece
May glory in such a choice, I have some business,
Excuse three minutes, I'll dispatch, and go
Along with you myself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How's that? he go? we must prevent that mischief.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Noble sir, what service can reward this goodness in you?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: If you acknowledge any benefit
From me, in that I am enough rewarded,
I wish you, what I cannot hope for, joy,
But yet we have not finished.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What do y' think? if ▪
'tis gone again, we must have some trick,
To get off without him.

div.stage: Enter servant with a letter to Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: From mistress Chrysolina?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What and we should set some on's house afire,
Do y' think he would stay to quench it? how has he
Lived all this while, and has no more diseases?
No honest gout to keep him warm at home,
In furs, no charitable ague, fall
Into his legs to stay him, no sciatica?
He is no gentleman he scapes so well.

p.quote: I love him above my life, but you have only his heart, he says; for which I languish, if you have power to dispose it, I will cherish some hope, he will love me, at least for your sake.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If he should with us, is't not possible
sp.p: He may have a fall, and break a leg, and 'twere but his neck, why may not some prentice throw a stone, and put an eye out, that he may go to th' surgeons, or some horse, or cartwheel squeeze his toe, and stay his journey?

p.quote: His noble carriage to you, made me first affect him, then since you are happy in another, let me owe to your virtue for his affection, without whom I am the most miserable — Chrysolina.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Let me entreat you sir, peruse that paper.
Sir you know Chrysolina?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do know her.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Poor gentlewoman is in love with Yongrave:
We have arrived at our desires already,
And want but the church sealing, she is lost,
Unless he meet her wishes, 'twill become
Our piety to advance, in what we may
The common cause of love, then briefly thus —

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Can any virgin affect me so much?
She did prepare this argument before.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: As you are charitable, go presently.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And leave you thus?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: We'll get off ▪ well enough:Eug. and Thor. whisper.
Pray her to meet us.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I do pity her,
And I have learned it from my sufferings;
but I must keep my word, Eugenia
Hath still my heart, and only can dispose it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Then I resign to her, in this alone,
I will deserve these noble offices.
You know the place.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'm perfect.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Love her, and let us all be happy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Sir, I must desire
You would excuse me, I would go with you,
But that I have considered, 'twill be better
That I should not appear, since you intend
To have it private, there will be less notice
If I be absent, and it may be thought
You by some trick stole her away: d'ye mark?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: Well thought on.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Then, sir, that opinion
Will save our credit, and excuse the want
Of ceremony, and the fruitless charge,
Which is expected at her marriage:
Is it not best?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: You show your providence.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Though I could wish your presence.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: You're not wise,
Eugenia, go to the church, and let me
Salute you quickly happy bride and bridegroom:
Away, I say.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He has prevented us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: The land's my own, you wrong your joys to tarry,
I would I had more nieces thus to marry. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Nay, never blush, but haste and meet the gentleman.
You have no reason to distrust me, lady,
After this circumstance.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Can I be so happy?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Have a strong faith, and find it so,
Though once I was guilty of some wrong to thee.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: Never to me: or if you had this news
Is recompense enough.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I'll tell thee now:
I was the cause that Gerard did neglect thee,
In hope to gain thee for myself; I told him
Thou hadst half consented to be mine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This truth?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Bade him direct his courtship to Aurelia,
And so be sure of one: poor gentleman
Believed, and after lost thy sister too:
But if no cure be seasonably applied,
Gerard, I fear, will sink beneath his loss.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Was this the cause?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I must accuse myself.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I'll tell Aurelia this.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Do so.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: She meant to visit him, but this will give her wings.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I will entreat her pardon, but make haste,
I would not willingly be seen.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I feel
Another soul, what raptures are distilled
Upon my heart? Enter Caperwit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: She cannot choose but take it.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: You know how to direct her, but be swift
In your return. — Mr. Caperwit?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Your servant ▪
Sir, if my sight be not unfaithful, I have seen you.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I owe much to your eyes,
It was my happiness to see you here.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I do remember.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I observed your courtship
To fair Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Pray sir, can you dance?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Dance?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I presume you are a friend to her,
Whose name made sweet your breath so late.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: It did not stink before.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Excuse my poetry.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I know you've heard wherein consists my excellence.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: You are a prince in poetry, and please your excellence.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The phrase in latin's modest, use no reverence,
To tell you true, you are a friend, I am upon a mask —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That made you ask if I could dance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis right, and you should do me honour
To lend your person to it, but I would
Have it this night, before my mistress, whose
Mention perfumed your lips so late.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Sweet language!
Wi' your favour, Mr. Caperwit, who are the
Principal maskers?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Faith I have none yet,
Beside myself, but a foolish knight, one sir Gervace,
and's lady, I want persons.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Let me furnish you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: And tie my everlasting friendship to you.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: They shall be of quality, most of your acquaintance ▪
What if Aurelia be one? she loves you,
I ha' discovered that; I know she'll do't,
Her sister for another, and myself,
Frank Gerard and Jack Yongrave, with his mistress.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The number I desire.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I know your lodging, say no more, I'll bring 'em,
This afternoon to practise, we may soon
Perfect a dance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Shall I trust to you?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I kiss it.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I may give you a hint perhaps for the device too.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I have no other gratitude but this,
Live but a week, I'll send you an ode; or die,
I'll write your epitaph. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: I have no purpose to put your muse
To such expense. Farewell phantasma.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Have I not been tedious?
I told my sister all, and she is gone
To Mr. Gerard, if their meeting prosper,
I have directed where to find us.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.l: Excellent, come, let's away,
A thousand joys expect us. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gerard in his gown and cap.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I once believed women were full of pity,
Of soft and gentle constitutions:
But I have found 'em cruel: for Aurelia,
One of the best of all her sex, doth own
A hard and tyrannous nature. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I prithee let it be undone, as I am.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The song,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I gave to be taught music? I'll hear't anon:
I prithee go —

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To prison.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yes, and ask when are the sessions.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: They are every month.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I would 'twere execution day tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why, with your pardon, do you wish it, sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I would entreat the surgeons to beg
Some woman for anatomy, nothing else:
I have heard their lectures very much commended,
And I'd be present when they read upon
Her heart: for sure there is much difference
Between a woman and a man, in that
Same thing we call a heart, they do not love
As we do; we are fools, indeed we are,
To dote so much upon 'em, and betray
The glory of our creation, to serve
A female pride; we were born free, and had
From the great maker royal privilege,
Most brave immunities: but since have made
Tame forfeit of our charter. Let me see't,
It is the same, first read it, reach the chair:
'Tis yet no song, infuse a soul into it.

div.head: Song.
div.l: If love his arrows shoot so fast,
Soon his feathered stock will waste:
But I mistake in thinking so,
Love's arrows in his quiver grow ▪
How can he want artillery?
That appears too true in me:
Two shafts feed upon my breast,
O, make it quiver for the rest,
Kill me with love, thou angry son
Of Cytherea, or let one,
One sharp golden arrow fly,
To wound her heart for whom I die.
Cupid, if thou beest a child,
Be no god, or be more mild.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I have not, since I served him, known him so
oppressed with melancholy; he's asleep,
I dare not wake him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I'll expect a while.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: This quiet will much benefit him, he
Began to talk idly.

sp.speaker: Aur ▪
sp.l: Heaven preserve the temper of his brain.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He wakes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha, 'tis not she, do I dream still;
Come hither, dost thou see nothing?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes, a gentlewoman that came to visit you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Do not abuse thy master, 'tis not possible Aurelia
Will do me so much honour; in my sleep
Methought I parled with her, and my fancy
Hath not yet lost her shape; o my Aurelia!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I come to ask thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Do not mock me ▪
Thou wilt be cruel when I wake again;
And than I shall repent I dreamt so sweetly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You're now awake, and I am your Aurelia,
That if you can forgive her past neglect,
Will give you proof of her repentance,
But these tears —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let not the ground be hallowed with
Such water, I have a heart to drink this balsam:
Enough Aurelia, do not make thy eyes
Poor, to enrich thy bosom, where the drops
Show like a carcanet of pearl upon it,
Thou hast enough restored me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O my Gerard!
Thou art too merciful, and dost forgive
Too soon the injury I did thy love;
But I am come to make thee satisfaction;
And this is but a shadow of those joys,
We must divide, if you vouchsafe to follow,
As I direct.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis sin not to obey.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You must walk then.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is to heaven thou goest.
Convey me swiftly thither.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis haste is now required.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What bliss can be denied,
A man that follows such an angel-guide? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p:
Where in the name of simplicity, should my master be all this while? I have been at six ordinaries, twelve taverns,
and I think four and twenty bawdy-houses, places that gentlemen use to frequent, and yet cannot find him: well, I am resolved to ask every man I meet; and if I cannot hear of him the sooner, I'll have him cried.
Pray did you see my master?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: Thy master? I know him not.

sp.speaker: Thump.
sp.p: Nay sir, did you see him? for if you see him, you cannot choose but know him; for he had a hundred marks brought him warm out of the country this morning.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: Much good do it him next his heart, I see him not. Ex.

sp.speaker: Thump.
sp.p: No, no; there is no hope, 'tis but an unmannerly trick of any master, to leave his man o'this fashion; 'tis well there is no press abroad, no disguised constables twelve pence, and the King's name would put me into a pitiful fever, and I should curse sir Gervace in another country, as often as I heard the report of a musket, for bringing me up no better, that might ha' hued quietly at home, and gone a feasting with the trained band without any danger.
Here is another youth, and his commodity, I'll inquire of him, pray did you see my master?

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: Thy master, what's he.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: A knight sir, I'll assure you, of the last edition that was my foolish master, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Sir Gervace simple.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: Something of a black complexion, with a weasel face.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: In a doublet of orange-tawny satin, richly laced? and blue trunk hose very suitable?

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Very right sir.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: A long Italian cloak came down to his elbows, a Spanish ruff, and long French stockings.

sp.speaker: Thump.
sp.p: Just the same, how happy was I to meet with this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: Faith honest friend, I saw none such.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Pox of these questions.

sp.speaker: Thor.
sp.p: But if thou'lt go with me, I may chance help to a sight of this pageant.

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: Heaven bless your worship, and the sweet faced modicum in your company. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: To prison with your servants husband; hang
Them all, unless they find our daughters.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: And I have sent to sir John Woodhamore's,
They may be with his niece.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: They never used
Thus to absent themselves; o me unhappy!

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: We have been too indulgent.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: I would have had them more restrained, young wenches
That have so many suitors, grow soon wanton,
And throw off their obedience; had you been
Forward as I, they had been married;
And than we had not suffered this perplexity.
I did commend an honourable man,
But your deliberation hath marred all,
And they were here again —

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Have patience wife,
They are not lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: No, no, lost?
They'll come again, double I warrant you,
And perhaps treble, with some unthrift husbands,
Of their own choosing.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: It does trouble me.
They were not used to walk abroad without
A servant, to wait on 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: You must think
They have servants of their own, for such a business,
Young maids have plenty of such waiting men,
And this has been a long conspiracy, I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: What hast found 'em yet?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I can hear no news,
And sir John Woodhamore is much troubled sir,
His niece is gone too.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Hey day!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sh'as been absent ▪
Ever since morning.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Precious, precious thieves!
Eugenia's gone, let's have 'em cried together.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: They that have found 'em, will too soon I fear,
Alter the property.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: We shall keep no virgins ith' town shortly.
Welcome sir John.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Is not my niece Eugenia here?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Not here.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: We have lost our daughters, and that's two for one.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Ours have been absent ever since the morning.
Nor can we study what's become on 'em

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Is't possible? is there no plot in this?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Our servants have inquired in every place.
Of our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: I will tell you sir,
You do remember master Yongrave.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: A servant of your nieces;

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: The same sir
With my consent, he took her forth this morning.
To marry her, I do believe he has don't,
But it doth wrack my brain, why they should stay thus,
They might have married, forty times by this.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: You did perhaps desire it private.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: And he too.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I will engage my life they are all together.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: I am confident, let's in to supper, and expect the best.
sp.stage: Enter servant, and whispers mistress Goldsworth.
sp.l: What news with him?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: 'Tis something that he says.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I cannot find 'em.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: But I have met a gentleman, that can
Tell you some news.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: That does concern my daughters?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: So he reports, he is a cunning man, I think a conjurer,
He talks of art, and spirits.
This is he sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Gentles in your troubled brow,
I read what you desire to know,
Let no fear invade your heart;
I will tell by powerful art,
Your children's fate, and where they are:
Know then, they are wandered far,
Led by Cupid God of loves,
They have now arrived those groves,
Where no happy soul can sleep,
Venus doth there revels keep.
Consecrating day and night,
To song, to kisses, and delight:
They in Elysium breath, choose whether,
They shall move thence, or you go thither.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: This is some poetical business.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Sweet husband let us go to 'em, I have heard poets talk much of Elysium, I would fain see whether they be honest of their words or no.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: No it will befit them to come to us.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It shall be so: harmonious strains,
That do bless those happy plains;
Usher them forth, and shame the spheres,
Charm with heavenlier notes our ears,
Recorders.that when we see the lovers come,
We may believe Elysium
Itself come hither, all those bowers,
And the shades of pleasure ours.

div.stage: Enter masked Yongrave, Chrysolina, Gerard, Aurelia, Thornay Eugenia, simple bird, between every couple a torch carried, they march over the stage, and exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.l: Who are all these?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: I guess some of them, o that I were in Elysium

sp.speaker: Vvood.
sp.l: What are they vanished? Another turn of your art good sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Chime other music.

sp.speaker: Vvoo.
sp.p: Now they will discover. Master Yongrave? I rejoiceYon. discovers.to see you here, this is the gentleman I praised so much, he has married now my niece.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But I must ask your blessing, we are married,

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Chris. unveils.ha, another sweetheart; I am abused, he is a very knave; where is my niece?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Is he worse for marrying of my child? nay, than my blessing on you both, my son and daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Aur. unveils.where's Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Here mother, I have met a husband too, let us divide your prayers — soft master CaperwitGer. discovers.we are married sir already.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How married? did not you promise me?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Master Gerard? nay and it be no worse I care not 〈◊〉 to my heart.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My duty shall deserve it, 'tis e'en so, good master Caperwit you must dance without her.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Have I made verses and studied speeches for this?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Since there's no remedy, I bless you both, but I didEug. unveils.wish —

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir: if you will acknowledge your niece.
You must accept a nephew too: we are as fast as they.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Death! I am cozened, cheated, there is law.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: And there is conscience.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I'll not give you a penny.

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.l: I will not publish sir your avarice,
Wish 'em good joy.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Well, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes faith uncle, we are coupled, man and wife.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I'll inquire how this came about hereafter;
Look you love her sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: As I will do my soul.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, all is not yet discovered; there are a pair behind, worth taking notice of; do y' know sir Gervace simple, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Simple as he stands there.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And this is my lady — what does thy hair come off already.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Your worship is a most egregious coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A boy? Gentlemen, have I married a boy, or is she metamorphized?

sp.speaker: Yon.
sp.p: Ha, ha, master Caperwit's page.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Give you joy sir.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: The bird is flown indeed la.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Bird? they make a coxcomb of me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I am glad somebody else is cozened beside myself;
Nay, nay take her, there is a man within a mile of an oak,
I name nobody , has had earnest of her body.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Bawdy quoth a Thump, I will sell thee my knighthood for half the money it cost me, and turn yeoman in the country again; why there is neither wit nor honesty in this.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Be ruled by me, let's to some tavern, and
Drink away melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ay, and then we may steal away disguised, a match!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Nay, nay, let's all together, and make a merry night on t, Sim. Why how now Thump, are you sneaking away?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Let's all together.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: But first we must the licence of these gentlemen.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: Our poet knows you will be just, but we
Appeal to mercy, he desires that ye
Would not distaste his muse, because of late
Transplanted, which would grow here, if no fate
Have an unlucky bode opinion
Comes hither but on crutches yet, the sun
Hath lent no beam to warm us, if this play
Proceed more fortunate, we shall bless the day,
And love that brought you hither; 'tis in you
To make a little sprig of laurel grow,
And spread into a grove, where you may sit,
And hear soft storeys, when by blasting it,
You gain no honour, though our ruins lie
To tell the spoils of your offended eye:
If not for what we are, for alas hear
No Roscious moves to charm your eyes, or ear,
Yet as you hope hereafter to see plays,
Encourage us and give our poet bays. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
